abstract.p: Because aerodynamic stall is a major potential cause of mechanical failure in axial fans, effective stall-warning techniques have had wide application for many years. The study assesses the application of stall-detection to a class of heavy-duty fans for induced draft service in coal-fired power plants. With a multi-MW installed power, this class of fans operates at constant rotational speed, utilising variable-pitch in motion blades to adjust fan duty point. This load modulation system, in the presence of blade erosion or fouling, could result in fans becoming prone to stall as a consequence of the reduced pressure capacity. This article reports on a novel methodology, first proposed for the early detection of stall in low-speed axial-flow fans for tunnel ventilation. With respect to the original concept, which was based on the analysis of hydrodynamic pressure as measured on the fan ducting, the investigation demonstrates the potential of processing far-field pressure signals in identifying stall pre-cursors, and in so doing, establishing the stall incipience. This acoustic stall-detection system is characterised in a laboratory environment exploring the fan operating envelope. Time-resolved pressure measurements are carried out with pre-polarised pressure transducers fitted into (a) the fan casing over the fan blades (near field) and (b) in the inlet plenum 1 diameter upstream of the fan rotor (far field). The evolution of the rotating stall for the fan under scrutiny is first presented. The rationale of the signal processing technique is given, together with a sensitivity study on its metrical parameters. Finally, the signal visualization technique is used to compare the patterns related to the presence of stall in the pressure signals recorded in the near- and the far field.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Axial fans are selected for induced draft systems steam power plants because of the higher aerodynamic efficiencies, relative to centrifugal blowers, at design and off-design operations. The load modulations, linked to the connection to the grid, directly reflect onto the flue gas volume and the system resistance and could turn into a 30% weekly-round modulation of the fan pressure rise in a typical large steam electric generation unit, with an overall system resistance of order o(104) Pa (see Van Beyer and Bolland1 and Fläkt Woods AktieBolag (AB), 2011, personal communication). To cope with this service, the induced draft fans are controlled by variable pitch in motion actuators, instead of dampers or inverters, which permit to adjust the fan duty point to any condition within the performance range.2,3

The load modulation and the exposure to severe erosion, in induced draft fan blades, combine and result in fans becoming prone to stall when attempting to operate beyond the actual pressure capacity. The standard classification of aerodynamic stalls, in axial fans and compressors,4 discriminates them according to the nature of the inception mechanism (spike or modal, for instance5), which is typically detected with probes evenly distributed around the casing upwind the rotor leading edge6 to characterise the annular region of reversed flow. The stall, by which the rotor adapts to a reduction in flow rate, results in circumferentially non-uniform flow patterns rotating in the annulus and in part-span regime, typically occurring in single-rotor or stage machines,7 it may lead to more complex disturbances than in multi-stage compressors.8 All of these forms of instability are even magnified in rotors operating under erosive regimes. In fact, after leading edge and blade surface wear, the recovering of pressure rise capability is actuated by increasing the pitch angle. As such the stall free operating margin of the fan reduces. This combination of factors places considerable mechanical stress on fan rotors, eventually leading to mechanical failure. Researchers have reported that strain gauge measurements on axial compressors9 and fans10 have bending stress in vanes exceeding stable operation by a factor of five and seven, respectively, under rotating stall conditions.

The development of techniques for the identification of stall as early as possible to enable an active control system to react is still a research subjects because of twofold motivations. First, there is no established warning system of general validity.11,12 Second, time scales for an early warning are two rotor revolutions for axial compressors and 10 times longer for industrial fans.13 This means they are, according to typical rotational frequencies, ranging from o(10−3 s) to o(10−1 s).

Because model-based stall-warning systems, the base-line in industrial turbomachinery, could not sense the deterioration of the rotating machines nor the modification in its operating environment, non-model based techniques have been considered for real-time control applications. These early warning techniques use diagnostic methods that are mostly based on time or Fourier analyses14–16 to derive a metric of the phenomenon, e.g. the stall-warning index proposed by Tahara et al.17 In this respect, Breugelmans et al.18 were the first that speculated on the chaotic dynamics associated with rotating stall bridging, attempting the description of the irregular behaviour during stall incipience and evolution with the mathematical ideas of deterministic chaos.19 The phase–space portraits of the experimental data series were constructed, comprising velocity, static pressure and vibration signals, by using the so-called method of delays formulated by Takens.20 In a similar vein, Bright et al.21 investigated rotating instabilities prior to stall with statistical temporal structure function of nature inspired from chaos theory. Owing to the universality of the periodic phenomena underlying the formation of rotating vortices during stall, its inception mechanisms has been correlated with a direct audible manifestation and a specific acoustic signature inspiring diagnostic techniques based on sound–signal visualisation.22 This approach to fault diagnosis in rotating machinery is suitable in the case of pressure signals dominated by discrete narrow and frequency components related to the rotor speed. Recently, Sheard et al.23 used sound visualization to assess the acoustic payoff in a class of low-solidity axial fans fitted with passive control of tip-leakage-generated noise.

This study demonstrates the use of sound–signal visualisation for early stall-warning detection. The technique was first conceived for the visual characterisation of speech waveforms and sound quality evaluation.24–26 In recent research efforts, the authors developed the proposed technique using the reconstruction of symmetrised dot pattern (SDP) images from hydrodynamic pressure signals27 and proved the use of pressure signal visualization to be effective in the early stall-warning of fans (utilising high-response transducers on the rotor casing).13 Against this background, this study extends the technique to the processing of pressure signals of acoustic quality recorded remotely from the fan and validates the stall detection capability when measuring the acoustic fluctuations in the far field, where the hydrodynamic pressure decays as the inverse third power of the distance to the fan rotor aerodynamic sources.

This study explores the use of the SDP-based stall diagnostics in detecting the stall incipience and evolution in an induced draft fan test rig at full speed. The research focuses on demonstrating the capability of the visualisation method with a low signal-to-noise ratio. In the current context, a low signal-to-noise ratio is defined as a low instability signature to background noise ratio. This working hypothesis is adopted to simulate the signal-to-noise ratio typical of real-life operational environments and enables to quantify the effectiveness of visual waveform analysis with the probe located in the far field.

sec.title: Test rig
sec.p:
This study was carried out in the induced draft test rig of a single stage axial fan, coded PFS (Pan Fläkt Single), typically used in coal-fired power plant. The tested PFS fan has a rotor with 18 unswept blades designed with a free vortex radial work distribution. Table 1 provides the specifications of the PFS fan, together with details of the induced draft setup of the test rig. Table 1.
Fan and test rig data.
Fan
Nominal pressure rise (Pa) 380
Nominal flow rate (m3/s) 13
Design efficiency, ηtot (–) 0.92
Tip diameter (mm) 1500
Blade chord at the tip (mm) 105
Average blade solidity (–) 0.6
Test rig
Volume flow rate range (m3/s) 6–52
System resistance (Pa) up to 5000

The fan was equipped with a mechanism for varying the blade pitch angle, with the rotor spinning, specifically the angular setting could range from 40° to 80°, as measured at the hub on the peripheral direction. The blade section was a single-parameter highly twisted C4 airfoils and the clearance between the blade tips and the casing is 1.3% of chord at tip.

The test facility complies with the ISO 5801:2007 standard, equivalent to the BS 848 Pt.1 standard.28 The motor drove the fan at a constant speed of 700 rpm. The blade tip velocity was 55.13 m/s. At this tip speed, the blade passing frequency (BPF) for all tested configurations was 210 Hz. The duct containing the fan exhausted into a plenum chamber equipped with a throttling valve at the top of the chamber to adapt the system resistance. The aerodynamic load of the rotor and the geometry of the downstream plenum ensured that the system could not develop a counter-pressure able to induce a surge and the value of the B parameter for the plenum configuration was 0.15.29

sec.title: Instrumentation
sec.p:
The test rig was instrumented with high-response probes to record the pressure fluctuations on the casing of the fan and in the inlet plenum, as illustrated in Figure 1. Figure 1 shows the position of the probes on the casing and in the inlet ducting. The fast response sensors are mounted flush with the ducting wall, each having a diameter of 15 mm, with a recess of approximately 0.5 mm, with a 10% reduction of the sensing area. Figure 1.
Position and mounting of near- and far-field probes.

For the near-field measurements, the fan rotor casing was instrumented with inserts containing the unsteady pressure probes because tip leakage flow usually triggers the inception of rotating stall and may therefore be regarded as one of the critical three-dimensional flow features. During the test, two pressure field microphones, with sensitivity –26.2 dB re 1 V/Pa, monitored the wall pressure at the casing of the fan. Similar sensor arrangements were effective in resolving the instantaneous casing pressure in a ventilating fan.13 For this reason, the probes were mounted azimuthally with an angular anomaly (θ of 60° at half-chord distance from the fan blade leading edge.

For the far-field measurements, the one pressure field microphone (sensitivity –26.2 dB re 1 V/Pa) was mounted 3 diameters from the rotor leading edge in the calm region of the inlet plenum. This arrangement reduces the direct influence of the airflow onto the acoustic pressure measurement.

A charge amplifier conditioned the microphones, with its output being routed to a digital data acquisition system with analogical input module. The duration of all the tests was about 160 s, to allow the fan time to throttle toward stall, and the sampling frequency was 10 kHz. The range of uncertainty for readings was 0.1–0.2 dB at 1 kHz, given by the probes calibration. The microphones and acquisition system were calibrated in accordance with the requirements of ISO IEC60651.30 The estimated error in pressure measurements, due to the turbulence, was about 2% of the signal and it is self-consistent with the average turbulence level at the rotor casing.31 Because of the interest in the reconstruction of the signal topology, the technique developed by the authors is not reliant on the absolute level of the measured quantity; thus the calibration of the probes was not relevant within the context of the proposed methodology.13,32

sec.title: Rotating stall dynamics
sec.p:
Figure 2 shows the pressure–volume operating envelope of the fan at full speed operation from 50° to 70° of the blade angle at the hub as measured to the peripheral direction (pitch angle), i.e. the reference settings. In particular, the characteristic line at 70° pitch angle also shows three operating points considered in the present study and labelled, resepctively: (D) for the design point, (P) for the peak pressure point and (S) for the stalled condition. The performance are measured in terms of total pressure rise and the chart was measured running the fan to unstable operation by gradually throttling the flow downstream. Each performance measurement sessions lasted 60 s whilst the stall sessions lasted 160 s. The total pressure rise was measured from the average exit − area total pressure and average inlet − area total pressure. The accuracy of pressure measurements was ± 0.5% of measured data for all probes and pressure taps. Figure 2.
Fan total pressure–volume operating envelope (dashed line: 50°, solid line: 70°).

sec.title: Near-field description of the stall
sec.p: The dynamics of the stall of the PFS fan in the induced draft rig was described by Bianchi et al.,3 using the near-field unsteady pressure sensors arrangement, by visual inspection and spectral analyses.

The qualitative inspection of the mechanism at play during the stall onset at 100% of nominal speed (700 rpm), within a time interval of 30 s whilst throttling the fan from stable to stalled operations, is based on pressure traces low-pass filtered at 150 Hz, as measured on the casing probes (Figure 3). Figure 3.
Pressure–time history for the probe flush mounted at the blade-tip region.

The pressure histories (Figure 3) do not provide evidence of a modal inception, but rotating disturbances occurred when the fan was operated at pressure rise higher than the designed one. Specifically, the first rotating disturbance occurred with the fan delivering a 410 Pa total pressure rise after 28 s from the start of the throttling sequence. According to the relative position on time abscissae,3 Bianchi and co-workers deduced that the pre-stall spike travelled at 70% of the rotor speed. After this spike, the pressure signal returned to a stable value for approximately three rotor revolutions, before evolving into a full stall. The evolution in a proper stall cell was indicated by the appearance of a second spike-like instability rotating at 50% of the shaft speed. This instability appeared at 28.5 s and featured a different profile similar to the embryonic stage of a proper stall cell.

Whilst the first spike (stall inception) was a time-concentrated single spike, the second one (embryonic stall) covered a larger time length. Approaching t = 30 s, the pressure signal provides evidence of the first appearance of the waveform one may associate with a rotating stall cell. This cell, as per the interaction among the set of faster pre-stall instabilities, moved at 40% of the rotor shaft speed.

Figure 4 shows the Fourier analysis of the pressure signal. The sampling period was 120 s, spanning from the peak flow rate condition to the stall event. The authors applied the FFT of the signals in a time window lasting 18 rotor revolutions, at the stall incipience Δt = 28.5–30 s (Figure 4(a)) and at full stall Δt = 50–1.5 s (Figure 4(b)). Figure 4.
Autospectra of the pressure signals during (a) the stall inception and (b) the stall.

Throttling the rotor to the peak pressure (Figure 4(a)), the Fourier analysis revealed low-frequency peaks, indicative of the inception of rotating stall operation, in agreement with results Kameier and Neise33 and Bianchi et al.34 have previously reported. Although the spectrum refers to a pre-stall behaviour, this low-tones featured a frequency close to that of the fully developed rotating stall cell.

Figure 4(b) demonstrates that, during the stall, the peak instability frequency was localised at 5 Hz with side band modulations. These side band modulations constitute harmonics of the wall pressure spectra at fan stall.3 It was possible to infer that, due to the aerodynamic characteristics of the studied fan rotor, the pressure disturbances originating as stall spots in the range 30–50 Hz during the stall incipience grew further, decreased their speed and merged with the spike-like stall cell located at 40% of the shaft rate.

sec.title: Far-field description of the stall
sec.p: A similar analysis of the stall evolution could be attempted with use of the single far-field probe that measured the unsteady acoustic pressure dynamics in the fan inlet plenum.

Figure 5, first, shows the pressure–time series for a time interval that extends after the stall inception time of 30 s in order to have a clear evidence of the phenomenon periodicity. The pressure trace is low-pass filtered at 150 Hz. Figure 6, then, illustrates the FFT of the far-field pressure signal in time windows lasting 18 rotor revolutions, at the stall incipience Δt = 28.5–30 s (Figure 6(a)) and at full stall Δt = 50–51.5 s (Figure 6(b)). Figure 5.
Normalised pressure time history for the probe flush mounted in the inlet plenum.
Figure 6.
Autospectra of the pressure signals during (a) the stall inception and (b) the stall.

sec.title: Signal visualization technique
sec.p: The rationale underpinning the proposed warning technique is to link topology and pressure signal dynamics (stall) in order to help visualise the range of possible behaviours of the system. In so doing, the technique shares its foundation with chaos theory.35 The underlying concept is that by visualizing a ‘shape’ of the phenomenon (this means by deriving a geometrical representation of the dynamics in time), it is possible to understand the system not only quantitative (power level produced by tonal components) but by qualitatively representing ‘howling’ and other modulated components.

The SDP technique provides a local visual correlation that one can apply to detect the significant features of any signal.23 As such, it was conceived for the visual characterisation of speech waveforms in automatic human-voice recognition algorithms.24 The merit of the methodology is its ability to perceive otherwise ‘unquantifiable’ differences in sound signals mimicking the human audition.25,26

sec.title: SDP phase–space portrait
sec.p: The first vector, providing the radius in the polar map (Ri), includes normalised values of the signal sampled with a constant time interval: the time lag L. The second vector, providing the angle in the polar map (Θi±), differs from the first one because it includes the normalised values of the signal but sampled constantly forward in time and amplified of an angular gain ξ. As such the position of any dot in the polar map represents the magnitude of the signal and its variation in time. The reconstruction of a scatter plot of neighbouring signal amplitudes on polar coordinates, the SDP space, is thus able to discriminate the frequency content of the signals and their variability. The time signal is analysed taking discrete sampling windows, with a time length TSDP, where N is the number of data in the sample. The input waveform first normalises in the range (0, 1) by finding the higher (Σ) and lower values (σ) for the N data points in the sampling window. Because of the interest in signal topology, the SDP portrait is not based on the absolute level of the measured quantity; thus the calibration of the probes was not relevant within the context of the SDP methodology.13,32 Overall amplitude is therefore not a factor in the characterisation.

The identification of stall precursors underpins the ability of the SDP methodology to provide a stall-warning capability. It is therefore important to consider the time taken to generate an SDP and therefore the significance of the number of points in a data series. The number of points in a data series is determined by the sampling frequency and the sampling time, with both impacting the features of the SDP patterns. This article aims to detect aerodynamic instability as stall precursor. As a consequence of the short time available to detect aerodynamic instability, establishing the minimum sampling frequency is key in the successful application of the SDP methodology. In a previous study on a fan for tunnel ventilation, the SDP technique demonstrated the ability to detect stall precursors in a time interval ranging from 0.1 s (at three revolutions) to 0.004 s (at one-tenth of a revolution).13 This confirmed the SDP technique’s potential as a diagnostic tool for the identification of pre-stall instabilities before the actual stall event itself occurs.

sec.title: Signal processing technique
sec.p: The microphones were used as pressure transducers, in the near- and in the far field, to resolve high-frequency variations in pressure whilst maintaining good sensitivity. The measurements were carried out at a sampling rate of 10 kHz with a Nyquist frequency of 5 kHz.

To avoid signal aliasing, the data are preliminarily filtered at 2.5 kHz and analysed in the range of interest below 200 Hz. The resulting Nyquist-rate was 1.2 kHz, which was largely below the sampling frequency, thus verifying the second condition on signal aliasing in the Nyquist problem. Although flush mounted, a small cavity is present in front of the diaphragm of the microphones. The cavities resonance frequency was 4702 Hz, calculated using the Helmholtz equation applied to an equivalent conical cavity.36

The estimated overall uncertainties on unsteady pressure measurements were: (a) ΔV = 1000 mV ± 12 mV (20:3) on the voltage and (b) ΔG = 200 dB ± 2.4 dB (20:3) on the raw signal gain in the range of considered frequencies. The estimated uncertainties could be accepted with respect to the highly unstable characteristics of the phenomena under scrutiny.37

sec.title: Remarks on the position of the probe
sec.p: The initial concept, proposed to develop the present stall detection technique, relied on monitoring the pressure fluctuations on the casing of the fan as it is peculiar to the state-of-the-art stall-warning systems.13 From an acoustic viewpoint, the pressure signal in the near field inevitably includes both aerodynamic causes and acoustic effects. Laurendeau et al.38 noted that the near-field spectrum consisted of a combination of a low-frequency range, dominated by the hydrodynamic signature, and a high-frequency range, influenced by the acoustic pressure fluctuations, the latter being the part of the signal that effectively excites progressive pressure waves.

For this reason, the stall detection was further developed by locating the probe in in the far-field region. The probe was set in the inflow plenum by locating the calm region where air-speed measurements revealed only a negligible airflow. This working condition was selected deliberately in order to attenuate the coupling mechanism of the hydrodynamic pressure fluctuations to the far field and to validate the stall detection response in a quiescent ambient fluid.

sec.title: Results
sec.p:
The pressure traces, recorded in the near- and far field, are analysed using the proposed SDP technique. The pressure signal analysis covers a range of operating points, which spans from near-design condition (point D) to full stall (point S) through the peak pressure operation (point P). Figure 8 shows the operating interval of the fan (at 70° hub pitch angle) plotted against the pressure–time signals, as recorded on the casing wall (near field) and in the plenum (far field). Figure 8.
Fan operating points and pressure traces (not scale).

sec.title: SDP parameterization
sec.p: In plotting SDP patterns, the methodology requires a choice of values for the parameters time lag L and the angular gain ξ. These parameters influence the topology of the polar mapping and in so doing the ability of the SDP to identify the aerodynamic phenomena of interest.

Based on the assumption of constant sampling frequency of 10 kHz, Table 3 summarizes the matrix of tests carried out to provide an insight into the sensitivity of the mapping to the metric of the transformation on both the near-field and the far-field pressure signals. Notably, the sensitivity studies refer to the design condition (point D) of the fan and to an unstable condition (point S). The SDP portraits are shown, for the sake of clarity, using a one-axis visualization. Table 3.

Figure 9 illustrates the sensitivity to the time lag L of SDPs drawn from the case-wall (Figure 9(a)) and the inlet plenum (Figure 9(b)) pressure signals. The time lag exerts a critical role in the reconstruction of the phase-space portrait when querying the pressure–time line during the fan throttling. Figure 9.
Sensitivity to L of (a) the near-field SDPs at TSDP = 0.5 s and ξ = 20° and (b) the far-field SDPs at TSDP = 0.5 s and ξ = 30°.
SDP: symmetrised dot pattern.

The template patterns in Figure 9 represent the variation of the signal topology when modifying the time delay magnitude used during data sampling. A comparison of the SDP portraits in the near field (Figure 9(a)) confirms that the use of a small time delay is unable to resolve the modification of the signal even in the presence of large fluctuations. For example, with L = 1, moving from D to S operation, the mapping does not provide evidence of curvature (frequency) changes but only the reduction of the normalised magnitude.

The template patterns in Figure 9(b) provide information as to the variation of signal topology when modifying the magnitude of the time delay used to sample the far-field pressure–time series. As seen in the near-field SDP analysis, the selection of delay time is a key element in reconstructing the signal’s dynamic content. In the acoustic pressure’s polar transformation, for instance, the use of L = 1 appears insensitive to changes in the signal as the fan approaches stall. Moreover, the time lag L = 1 is unable to reproduce the change in the frequency of the signal that is captured in its curvature.

A sensitivity study on TSDP is crucial in establishing the applicability of the present technique of static pressure signal visual mapping and the comparison of the patterns, irrespective to the location of the probe, provides insight into the robustness of the proposed methodology. Figure 10 illustrates the sensitivity to the sampling time of the SDPs of the case-wall pressure signals when operating at design point D measuring the hydrodynamic pressure (Figure 10(a)) or the acoustic pressure (Figure 10(b)). The dot patterns in Figure 10 illustrate the variation in the topology of the signal when reducing the SDP sampling time from five rotor revolutions (equivalent to 0.5 s) to one rotor revolution (equivalent to 0.1 s) or 0.5 rotor revolution (equivalent to 0.05 s). Figure 10.
Sensitivity to TSDP of (a) the near-field SDPs at L = 40 and ξ = 30° and (b) the far-field SDPs at L = 20 and ξ = 50°.
SDP: symmetrised dot pattern.

When reducing the sampling time by a factor of 10, the shape (or more specifically, the outline) of the portraits appeared unaffected by the duration of the data recording. In contrast, a link between the sampling time and the population of dots within the SDP patterns was common to both near- and far-field portraits. Nevertheless, the SDP stall-warning approach appeared able to dissect the dynamic content of the static pressure signals even at the 0.5 revolution scale, as indicated by the plot comparison at the stall. Specific to the stall onset, at P operation, there is evidence of multiple curvature branches in the SDP that point to the capability of the SDP technique in resolving the presence of fluid structure at different rotational frequency.13 Figure 10(b), in the far field, demonstrates that the capability of sensing the actual operation of the fan through phase–space portraits, to a lesser extent, is also evident when reducing the time duration for the applied method. The possibility of discriminating between stable and unstable operation (with data recorded over 0.5 rotor revolutions) is a key factor in the development of an effective early warning technique.

sec.title: Summary on the stall detection
sec.p: The capability to discriminate between the SDP patterns, when comparing different duty points, was demonstrated irrespective of the actual choice of the SDP metric parameters. The choice of the metric parameters did however influence the shape of the portraits. The use of larger time lag L, for instance, magnifies the pattern differences primarily because of the unbias when reading the near-field pressure signal. This is dominated by blade passage related effects and L = 1 transformations tend to assume monotone curvature behaviour. The comparison of plots (Figures 9 and 10) indicates that the mapping of the hydrodynamic pressure does not improve with an increase in angular amplification.

When considering the role of the SDP methodologies in a stall-warning application, the primary finding is that the SDP maps feature a reduced sensitivity to the duration of the sampling window TSDP. A clear differentiation of the SDP patterns, a mandatory pre-condition for a stall-warning technique, is evident both using multi-revolution and part-revolution sampling.

When studying the SDPs reconstructed from the acoustic pressure signal, different but unique features of the SDP may be identified when reducing the flow rate out of the stable range. However, the acoustic pressure modulations still reflect the evolution of identifiable SDP patterns. In contrast with the near field, the sensitivity analysis demonstrated a much richer dependence of the SDP map on the selection of parameters. First, the SDP differentiation appeared more reliant on the value of L.

As such the unit lag setting appears unable to discriminate among the diverse operating conditions. A similar indication of the importance of L to the formation of an SDP is evident for the angular gain ξ, which strongly affects the aerial extension of the polar patterns. In contrast, the far-field analysis confirms that the stall detection potential is not limited by the sampling time window duration and consequently the population of data points used to construct the SDP.

Finally, strictly correlated with the increased noise-to-signal ratio in the far field, the SDP patterns tend to be less dominated by monotone frequency content. This is a consequence of the attenuation of the blade-related frequency forcing. The approach to stall through the instability onset correlated with the presence of regular patterns as per the acoustic mapping of the system of rotating instabilities.

sec.title: Comparison of near-field to far-field SDPs
sec.p:
In order to complement the sensitivity analyses, Figure 11 illustrates the evolution of SDP maps during the variation of fan operating conditions. In particular, Figure 11 compares the reconstructed SDPs on the basis of the near-field static pressure signal to those reconstructed on the basis of the far-field acoustic pressure signal. Figure 11.
Near- and far-field SDP evolution stable to stall (a) at TSDP = 5 revs and (b) TSDP = 0.5 revs.
SDP: symmetrised dot pattern.

The two collections of maps illustrate the modification of SDP shape along the operating line of the fan. The authors used the following parameters for polar transformation: (a) L = 40, ξ = 20° and TSDP = 5 revs on near-field pressure and (b) L = 20, ξ = 30° and TSDP = 5 revs on far-field pressure.

Looking first to the mapping of the near-field signal, one can dissect two major differences when considering the pattern evolution toward the stalled operations (according to a counter-clockwise rotation). First, the SDP arms are gradually losing their curvature. This signifies the predominance of low-frequency components in the rotating stall operation.13 Second, the footprint in the SDP map extends with the appearance of increasing instability in the pressure time history at full stall.

When studying the SDPs reconstructed from the acoustic pressure signal, different but unique modifications of the SDP shape may be observed when reducing the flow rate out of the stable range. Specifically, SDPs show a tendency to lose curvature with the dominance of low-frequency content (the on-set of rotating stall frequency). This loss of curvature coexists with a reduction of the extension of radial area covered by the dot patterns that the authors correlated to SDP topology that was similar to white noise signals.13

sec.title: Implementation issues
sec.p: Drawing on the above findings, the proposed SDP-based stall-detection approach could be either based on hydrodynamic or acoustic pressure measurements. From the perspective of those industrialists tasked with implementing the stall-warning system, use of acoustic pressure measurements is preferable. The probe can be remote from the fan and still record acoustic signals that enable deduction of the fan operating condition.

Transformation of the input data into an SDP is performed remote from the fan. The warning logic is then driven by a system for template matching, which is similar to the digital image processing method used to compare image patterns in speech recognition systems. For the fan diagnosis, engineers use the measured unknown signal pattern as input into a template-matching system that forms a part of the data recording and analysis system. The unknown pattern is compared with the library of patterns, with a matching system used to find the best matching pattern from the available library. The ‘best match’ pattern is the operative condition pattern for the experiment, thus enabling the control system to act appropriately.
The complete measurement chain23 results in an estimated time for pressure signal conversion and SDP processing between 100 and 10 ms, according to the data converter technology.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The research reported in this article assessed a novel diagnostic methodology for the early detection of stall in induced draft axial-flow fans, in coal-fired power plant application.

The rationale of the proposed warning technique is to link topology and stall dynamics in order to discriminate between stable and unstable operations, not on a quantitative base only (sound-power level produced by tonal components) but also using a qualitative approach that characterises ‘howling’ and modulated sound components. The authors based the proposed diagnostic technique on a pressure signal’s polar transformation with a constant delay time, called time lag, in a similar fashion to the phase–space portrait reconstruction method. Because of the interest in the reconstruction of the signal topology, the technique is not reliant on the level of the measured quantity; as a consequence, the calibration of the probes was not significant. Nonetheless, the use of the method in the diagnosis of a signal requires a knowledge of the phenomena to be detected.

The experimental investigation focused on the evolution of transient unsteady pressure, which the authors recorded with microphones in the near field on the fan casing and in the far field in the inlet plenum upstream of the fan rotor. The results demonstrated that the proposed diagnostic algorithm is able to effectively diagnose early signs of stall. In particular, SDPs effectively detect non-conformity in the pressure waves when disturbances are only slightly larger than the background signals and are periodic in nature.

The article demonstrated, using both static pressure and acoustic pressure measurements, the possibility of identifying the presence of pressure instabilities (at stall incipience or rotating stall) with data recoded over as little as 0.5 rotor revolutions. Together with the validity of the technique in the far field, the above establishes the potential of the proposed diagnostic approach for use as the basis of an early warning stall warning technique and consequently the key component in an active stall control system.
